_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: All components of HCl equipment are inspected, maintianed, and tested according to 68.73 of this RMP.  Daily visual inspections are performed for all HCl equipment listed in 68.65 of this RMP.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Anticline Disposal, LLC?s Jensen Facility is located at 93 North Jonah (Middle Crest) Road, approximately 1?mile south of Boulder South Road (County Road 106) in Sublette County, Wyoming.  The facility treats and cleans produced and ?frac? water from oil and gas fields in southwest Wyoming.  The stationary sources of regulated substance are:

1. Two (2) 12,150 gallon storage tanks of 37 percent hydrochloric acid (HCl) and associated piping.  If the tanks were filled to 100 percent capacity, the result would be a maximum of 24,300?gallons or 241,168?pounds (lbs) of HCl, which is above the U.S. Environment Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Plan (RMP) threshold of 15,000 lbs.  Tanks will not be filled more than 90?percent of capacity (217,051 lbs maximum).  HC1 is separately introduced at different injection points along the water treatment system and never mixed with any other chemicals prior to injection into a one-million gallon bioreactor tank, where it is used for pH control.  GE Water & Process Technologies has provided the facility a ZeeWeed Wastewater Treatment System designed to treat an average daily flow of 820?U.S. gallons per minute (gpm) of wastewater to produce high-quality water for discharge to a nearby river.  This wastewater treatment system consists of a Bioreactor for the ZeeWeed system; two (2) ZeeWeed trains, each with five (5)?ZW 500D cassettes containing 48 modules; backpulse system; system Aeration equipment; Clean In Place (CIP) equipment; chemical dosing equipment; reverse osmosis (RO) pre-treatment equipment; two (2) single pass, two-stage RO units, each containing 85?membrane modules; and three (3) boron exchange pressure vessels.
2. One 12,000 liquid gallon anhydrous ammonia (NH3) tank and associated piping.  Maximum fill of 90% would result in 55,620 lbs of anhydrous ammonia, which is above the EPA RMP threshold of 10,000 lbs.  The ammonia injection system starts with the storage tank.  From this storage tank, the ammonia gas f

storage tank failure resulting in a liquid spill and vaporization of 9,600 gallons of anhydrous ammonia. Per 2004 changes to the RMP reporting rule, the results of the offsite consequence are not provided in the Executive Summary.  The facility has no reportable spill history.
